subject: US MARKET WRAP 9th August 2019: Trade concerns and European political risk leave havens bid into the weekend
content:
• SNAPSHOT: Equities down, Treasuries down, Dollar down, Crude up.
  • REAR VIEW: Trump says Sept talks with China could be cancelled; China reportedly charters tanker to ship US crude to China. UK GDP contracts in Q2; Italy govt faces confidence vote, possibility of elections in October; IEA cuts 2019 global oil demand growth view; Canada jobs report misses expectations.
  • COMING UP: TUE: German CPI, UK Labour Market Report, German ZEW, US CPI. WED: Australian Wage Price Index, Chinese Industrial Production, Retail Sales, German GDP, Swedish CPI, UK CPI, PPI and RPI, EZ GDP. THU: Australian Employment Report, Norges Bank, UK Retail Sales, US Philly Fed, NY Empire State Manufacturing, Retail Sales, Industrial Production. FRI: OPEC Monthly Report, Eurozone Trade Balance, US Building Permits, Housing Starts, Uni. Of Michigan. To download the report, please click here.

* MARKET WRAP: Risk sentiment was sour after US President Trump stated that the US and China were in talks, but he was not yet ready to strike a deal, adding to concerns of a global growth slowdown, and stoking fears of recession once again. Markets, however, had a mixed feel – although equities are mostly red, safe haven Treasuries are also lower, but crude trades firm with some citing technical factors and short-covering. In FX, the dollar index trades with an offered tone, and gold continues to consolidate around USD 1500. In afternoon trade, there was a bounce in risk, after the White House “clarified” Trump’s earlier comments on Huawei; Trump is quoted as saying “we’re not doing business with Huawei”, although the White House suggested that Trump was only referring to the ban on Federal departments buying from Huawei, but the Commerce Department process for special licenses was still going forward. Sources also reported that China had chartered a super tanker to transport its first US cargo since the recent tariff threats from the US. Meanwhile, Italian concerns are once again being thrusted into the forefront of trader’s minds, with Italy’s Senate due to convene on Monday to lay out the timetable for a confidence vote on the government, which with a medium-term view, carries some risk of elections in October. After market, attention will be on Fitch’s review of Italian ratings.

* TRUMP: US President Trump said the US was doing very well, and is still talking to China, but is not going to make a deal right now, going as far as to say that September’s talks with China might be cancelled. Trump seemed to suggest that the US had deferred its Huawei licensing decision after China stopped buying US agriculture, saying “we will not be doing business” with the tech giant, but caveated that this could change in the event of a US-China deal. The market had interpreted these comments to mean “the whole of the US will not be doing business with Huawei”; however, White House later clarified these remarks, saying that, Trump was only referring to the ban on Federal departments buying from Huawei, but the Commerce Department process for special licenses was still going forward. Trump again took aim at the Fed, calling for 100bps of cuts. On the dollar, Trump said the USD was the safest bet, but its strength was hurting US manufacturers; however, he said that he would not devalue the dollar since there is no need. Finally, Trump said he received a “beautiful” letter from North Korean Leader Kim, and thinks he will have another meeting with the leader.

* ITALY: Italy’s right-wing League party has introduced a no-confidence motion against PM Conte. The Italian senate will convene on Monday to set the timetable for a no-confidence vote against the government. The relationship between the League party and the 5-Star Movement reached breaking point over a project for a railway between Italy and France (TAV), as parliament rejected a motion by 5SM to block the plan. Thus, Italian Deputy PM/League Leader Salvini has called for a snap election after claiming that there is no longer a majority to support the coalition. Deputy PM Salvini reportedly favours 13th October as a date for an election, although others noted that President Mattarella is mulling 23rd October, subject to the timing of the confidence vote. Salvini is currently pressing for a parliamentary debate next week, while reports stated that the 5SM favours one after the 15th August national holiday. Following the confidence vote, it rests with Mattarella to dissolve the government and decide whether the next steps would be a general election, or the installation of a technocratic government, to pass the Autumn 2020 budget. Reports also speculated that the President could seek a “guarantee government”, i.e. a coalition that can manage. Salvini has dismissed this notion as undemocratic, and favours elections (note, Salvini’s Lega party currently lead the polls at approximately 38%).

* CANADA JOBS REPORT: A weak jobs report, with the headline printing a decline of 24k in July vs. expectations of +12.5k. Both full- and part-time jobs declined, while the unemployment rate rose by 0.2ppts to 5.7% (was expected unchanged), as the participation rate slipped by one-tenth to 65.6%. It wasn't really surprising, Canadian bank RBC said: "Outsized growth in prior months has for some time looked out-of-step with other measures of economic growth like GDP," adding that "the employment numbers are also notoriously volatile, which is why Statistics Canada could still legitimately characterize the 24k drop in July as 'little-changed.'" The bank also notes that the July data was still up by +353k from year-ago levels, a rate it says is tough to sustain. The bank suggests that the rise in the jobless rate was a little more surprising, but says that increases over the last two months have still not reversed the unusually large 0.3ppts dip to 5.4% in May. It is still down some 0.2ppts vs a year ago, and still sits around multi-decade lows. RBC also notes that wage growth, which has been a missing ingredient in indicators of late, jumped to a fresh cycle-high 4.5% Y/Y from 3.6%, extending earlier signs of improvement in Q2. "Worries about the potential impact on Canada from escalating US-China trade tensions will persist," RBC says, "and we still fully expect employment growth to be softer over the second-half of this year than it was over the first." However, the bank says details of the July report are still not really soft enough to change the narrative that Canadian labour markets still look pretty solid on balance.

* US PPI: Headline PPI rose +0.2% M/M, although the core measure fell by 0.1% M/M (first decline in four years); the underlying trend rate also weakened, with core metric easing to 1.7% from 2.1% previously. "Producer price inflation is expected to ease further, adding more reason for the Fed to implement two more 25bps rate cuts in six months during this 'mid-cycle adjustment'," Oxford Economics said.

* UK Q2 GDP: Prelim GDP data for Q2 contracted by 0.2%, against an expected unchanged reading and a prior 0.5%, the first quarterly contraction since 2012. Patheon Macroeconomics does not see a technical recession ahead, and looks for a recovery to +0.4% Q/Q growth in Q3, “as the impetus from stockpiling turns positive again and as growth in households’ spending remains strong”. Regarding the implications on BoE policy; the consultancy notes that the sub-zero print is likely to increase bets that the central bank’s next move will be a rate cut (note: markets now price a 70% chance of a cut by next January), however, Pantheon cautions that with recent GBP depreciation, combined with the prospect of fiscal stimulus, now is not the time for fresh monetary stimulus. Provided no-deal is averted, Pantheon expects the BoE to stand pat this year.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES SETTLE 7+ TICKS LOWER AT 129-22. Treasuries were positive in early trade, on the familiar concerns of slowing global growth, and the reintroduction of political risk in Europe courtesy of Italy, while UK growth contracting in Q2 did little to help. However, in later trade, yields moved higher, leaving the curve slightly steeper, with major curve spreads modestly wider to the tune of 1-2bps at settlement; the afternoon bounce was due to the White House ‘clarifying’ comments President Trump made on Huawei. On the week, the curve has bull flattened (on the week: 2s -9bps, 5s -11bps, 10s -12bps, and 30s -14bps).

* IRAN: US Defence Secretary Esper has asked South Korea to send troops to the Strait of Hormuz, Yonhap reported, coming amid the US’ efforts to gain international support for its maritime security mission through the Persian Gulf. Iran Foreign Minister Zarif later said the Persian Gulf is a vital lifeline and therefore a national security problem for Iran, and that Iran will not hesitate to safeguard its security; a spokesperson for the Iranian Foreign Ministry also said that if Israel were to join the US lead mission, it would interpret it as a threat to national security and would take adequate counter-measures.

* IEA: The IEA cut its 2019 oil demand growth estimate by 100k BPD to 1.1mln BPD and cut its 2020 by 50k BPD to 1.3mln BPD. The IEA report takes a similar view to the EIA’s earlier in the week, where it cut its 2019 world oil demand growth forecast by 70k BPD to 1.0mln BPD y/y. However, in contrast to the IEA cutting 2020 oil demand growth outlook, the EIA raised 2020 world oil demand growth by 30k bpd to 1.43mln BPD y/y increase. As a side note, the OPEC monthly report is due to be released on Friday 16th August, note this is a rescheduled release due to the Eid Al-Adha holiday.

* WTI FUTURES (U9) SETTLE USD 1.96 HIGHER AT USD 54.50/BBL; BRENT (V9) SETTLES USD 1.15 HIGHER AT USD 58.53/BBL. Crude continued to recover on Friday in what was a more technically driven session, although the major crude benchmarks are still lower on the week. Prices were edging higher in European trade before both benchmarks hit resistance levels at the 5DMA, and then broke out to the upside. Participants will be focusing on whether this bounce back can feed through into next week, or whether any new developments in the US-China trade conflict provides a fresh bout of selling on oil demand concerns; this weekend risk is likely to have provided some short covering, evident in Friday’s tape action. There were also reports that China has chartered its first US crude cargo since the most recent tariff threat from US President Trump, which was providing support to the complex, and further compressing the arb between WTI and Brent. On the outlook, PVM’s analysts are cautious, “accordingly, any recovery in risk appetite should not be taken for granted, especially given that there appears little hope for a swift resolution to the US-Sino trade spat.” Whereas UBS is worried that the market remains “excessively focused” on the demand side, seeing the recent sell off as “unquestionably an overreaction”, but does caveat that upside is limited until progress is made on US-China trade. In supply news flow, which has been on the back seat recently, Russia's oil production has reportedly increased to 11.32mln BPD between August 1st-8th (prev. 11.15mln BPD in July); Libya's El Sharara oil field (300k BPD capacity) is currently running at 70k BPD (vs 45k BPD on Thursday) following the restart yesterday. The latest Baker Hughes Rig Count in the US had oil rigs -6 at 764, gas rigs -2 at 169, and total rigs -8 at 934, where drillers cut rigs for the sixth consecutive week.

* STOCKS: S&P500 -0.7% at 2919, Dow Jones -0.3% at 26287, Nasdaq-100 -1.0% at 7646. SECTORS: consumer discretionary -1.0%, consumer staples -0.6%, energy -1.25%, financials -0.3%, health care +0.2%, industrials -0.8%, IT -1.25%, materials -0.7%, telecoms -0.8%, utilities +0.0%. 

* TECH STOCKS: Semis (SOX) were hit overnight following reports the White House is delaying the license decision for US companies to restart business with Huawei. The decision comes as China halts US agricultural imports. Trump also stated “we’re not doing business with Huawei” however, the White House later tempered his comments. Tech stocks were also dragged lower following poor earnings results from DXC Tech (DXC), which fell over 30% on Friday as it lowered its FY forecast which led to a slew of price target cuts. Other names lower in the space include Microchip (MCHP), Micron (MU), Nvidia (NVDA) & Xilinx (XLNX).

* M&A: Broadcom (AVGO) traded over 3% higher as it officially announced it will acquire Symantec’s (SYMC) enterprise security assets for USD 10.7bln, which is intended to be financed with proceeds from new committed debt financing; SYMC traded lower. CBS reported strong earnings however was an underperformer on the day as BMO noted that despite earnings, estimates and targets were lower and believe investors are more focused on the potential M&A.

* EARNINGS: Uber (UBER) were hit after misses on both EPS and revenue, as well as gross bookings. Activision Blizzard (ATVI) were hit after poor forecasts, outweighing the beats on the quarterly figures.  Dropbox’s (DBX) figures were in line with street estimates, however, it was hit as it reported the slowest growth in paid users since its IPO. Nektar (NKTR) are lower by over 30% as it missed on revenue and disclosed a manufacturing discrepancy in its cancer drug. This was followed by a slew of price target downgrading with Mizuho cutting it from USD 79 to USD 21 with a neutral rating, and BMO cutting price target to USD 41 from USD 79. Kraft-Heinz (KHC) and Monster Beverages (MNST) were lower after earnings.

* FX WRAP: There was a risk-off configuration to FX trading at the end of the week: havens JPY and CHF advanced, EMFX was under pressure, carry was getting hit; EUR continues to trade magnetically to the 1.12 handle, amid a stable yuan fix that caused little drama overnight. The GBP meanwhile fell after data showed a growth contraction in Q2, though holds above 1.2050. CAD was slammed after soft jobs data, though analysts don’t think it changes the dial much for the BOC; USDCAD jumped, but couldn’t eat through offers around 1.3280. The antipodes were lower with risk. DXY is flat around 97.50, weighed on by further criticism from Trump of the Fed. Commodity FX was mixed; the RUB couldn’t participate in the crude rally, though NOK is higher, with desks suggesting positioning plays were seen ahead of next week’s Norges Bank meeting.

* WEEKLY FX WRAP: USD: Aside from a spike on Monday just over 98.000, the DXY has been remarkably rangebound and largely tethered to the 97.500 level amidst choppy risk sentiment and Dollar divergence vs is currency counterparts (G10 and EM). In fact, after hitting a 98.109 when the PBoC turned a blind eye to the YUAN weakening through a previously perceived 7.0000 red line against the Greenback, the index has been in an ever-decreasing circle tapering to just 97.649-487 on Friday, thus far. US data has hardly been a factor or impactor, as the focus has firmly rested on heightened US-China tensions over additional tariffs and Beijing suspending its purchases of agricultural products in response, while gradually devaluing the Cny, and Cnh by default if not design. President Trump and the White House have declared that China is manipulating its currency, with the former also renewing his criticism of the Fed in the midst of several other Central Banks cutting benchmark rates by more than expected or even when not forecast to do so at all.

* GBP: Sterling has been precarious all week (if not ever since hard-line Brexiteer UK PM) with recovery rallies in Cable confined to only a few pips above 1.2200 and fleeting, while retreats in Eur/Gbp through 0.9200 have been shallow. However, the final straw for Sterling came via Q2 GDP showing a 0.2% q/q contraction vs flat consensus, and Cable eventually caved into a fresh multi-year low circa 1.2055 as the cross eclipsed Thursday’s 2 year peak and edged closer towards 0.9300.

* JPY, CHF: In stark contrast, the traditional safe-havens are on course for healthy net gains vs the Buck and other peers, with Usd/Jpy much nearer the base of a 107.05-105.50 band and Usd/Chf also closer to 0.9695 than 0.9840. Firmer than forecast Japanese GDP and in line Swiss unemployment updates did not really prompt any reaction as broader swings between risk appetite and aversion dictated direction, while the Yen also maintained its correlation with UST yields (and spreads to JGBs).

* EUR: The single currency has benefited from its status as a pseudo or semi safe-haven amidst speculation that China could be buying/recycling Usds into Euros and cash flowing from EMs may be finding a home in the Eur. Hence, Eur/Usd recovered well from worst levels around 1.1105 to 1.1250 at one stage before losing momentum and spending the bulk of the week pivoting 1.1200 amidst renewed Italian coalition Government party angst that culminated in League Deputy PM Salvini calling for a new election given irrevocable differences with 5-Star Movement. First up, a vote of no confidence and date to be fixed next Monday.

* NZD, AUD, CAD: The non-US Dollars have endured, if not exactly enjoyed hectic weeks, with the Kiwi clattered by the RBNZ opting to cut the OCR by 50 bp rather than the ¼ point anticipated and priced in, while Governor Orr and his assistant Hawkesby embellished a dovish accompanying statement and guidance with post-policy meeting comments signalling further easing (perhaps even sub-zero vs the current 1% all time low). Hence, Nzd/Usd is hovering closer to the bottom of a 0.6380-0.6585 band and Aud/Nzd is just shy of 1.0500 within 1.0520-1.0265 extremes as Aud/Usd reclaims 0.6800+ status from 0.6680 or so at one stage. For the Aussie, next Thursday’s labour report looks pivotal given RBA rhetoric and the SOMP stressing the importance of jobs as Lowe and co maintain an loosening bias, but see tentative signs that the economy is turning for the better. Staying with jobs, the Loonie has been undermined by broadly disappointing data for July as headline payrolls declined, and not only due to temporary hiring, while the unemployment rate rose and together more than offset a cycle high wage component. Usd/Cad currently around 1.3240 vs 1.3175 and 1.3345 bounds, with another firm rebound in crude in the mix and countering the latest swing in overall risk sentiment after successive moves from aversion to appetite over the course of the week.

* NOK, SEK: The Norwegian Krona is gleaning some traction from the short squeeze in oil as well, but the Scandi Crowns have been mainly tracking general fluctuations in risk with a strong technical bent. Eur/Nok and Eur/Sek are now circa 9.9475 and 10.6900 vs 10.0960+ and 10.8350+ at the highs with the former eyeing next week’s Norges Bank meeting to see if a September hike is still on the cards or the Central Bank folds given no less than 6 peers easing this week in the face of heightened growth concerns (not to mention slower economic expansion levels already evident).

* EM: Contrasting fortunes across the region, with the Inr and Thb moving in opposite directions after the RBI lopped 35 bp off benchmark rates vs -1/4 point expected and the BoT deciding to cut 25 bp vs unchanged forecast, unlike the BSP, Serbian and Peruvian Central Banks that all delivered ¼ point eases in line with expectations. Meanwhile, the Try continues to outperform with the aid of not as high as feared Turkish CPI and CBRT tweaks to RRRs, while the Zar and Brl lagged/weakened markedly amidst poor SA data and despite Brazil passing its pension reforms.

ANALYSIS: Fitch is due to review Italy sovereign ratings (BBB/negative) after the close today
content:
• Fitch currently rates Italy BBB/negative outlook, the same as S&P, and one notch higher than Moody's rating (Moody's rates the country at Baa3, stable).
  • Analysts at UBS say it is reasonable to expect the current rating to stand, given it was affirmed in February. "Whilst concerns around Italy’s fiscal situation remain, an early-June confrontation with the European Commission over its deficit was averted when the country cut its deficit target," UBS says, "besides, Italy’s situation hasn’t changed since February in a way to indicate it will receive a negative rating action from Fitch (ie, weaker GDP is offset by adequate budget execution and low rates; political uncertainty is ever-present but there has not been any notable change in the period, plus its budget is on track; and there haven’t been any adverse developments in the banking sector to increase risks to the real economy or public finances)."
  • Some desks have suggested that, given the recent rise in tensions, and the prospects of a government collapse/general elections, Fitch could opt to wait to see how events play out immediately before it updates its rating. We saw a similar position taken by Moody's recently on South Africa, though the market took that strategy as a negative, and the rand was slammed in the following Monday's trade.

subject: Weekly FX Wrap: multiple Central Bank strikes as global trade wars intensify
content:

In stark contrast, the traditional safe-havens are on course for healthy net gains vs the Buck and other peers, with Usd/Jpy much nearer the base of a 107.05-105.50 band and Usd/Chf also closer to 0.9695 than 0.9840. Firmer than forecast Japanese GDP and in line Swiss unemployment updates did not really prompt any reaction as broader swings between risk appetite and aversion dictated direction, while the Yen also maintained its correlation with UST yields (and spreads to JGBs).

NZD/AUD/CAD

The non-US Dollars have endured, if not exactly enjoyed hectic weeks, with the Kiwi clattered by the RBNZ opting to cut the OCR by 50 bp rather than the ¼ point anticipated and priced in, while Governor Orr and his assistant Hawkesby embellished a dovish accompanying statement and guidance with post-policy meeting comments signalling further easing (perhaps even sub-zero vs the current 1% all time low). Hence, Nzd/Usd is hovering closer to the bottom of a 0.6380-0.6585 band and Aud/Nzd is just shy of 1.0500 within 1.0520-1.0265 extremes as Aud/Usd reclaims 0.6800+ status from 0.6680 or so at one stage. For the Aussie, next Thursday’s labour report looks pivotal given RBA rhetoric and the SOMP stressing the importance of jobs as Lowe and co maintain an loosening bias, but see tentative signs that the economy is turning for the better. Staying with jobs, the Loonie has been undermined by broadly disappointing data for July as headline payrolls declined, and not only due to temporary hiring, while the unemployment rate rose and together more than offset a cycle high wage component. Usd/Cad currently around 1.3240 vs 1.3175 and 1.3345 bounds, with another firm rebound in crude in the mix and countering the latest swing in overall risk sentiment after successive moves from aversion to appetite over the course of the week.

NOK/SEK

The Norwegian Krona is gleaning some traction from the short squeeze in oil as well, but the Scandi Crowns have been mainly tracking general fluctuations in risk with a strong technical bent. Eur/Nok and Eur/Sek are now circa 9.9475 and 10.6900 vs 10.0960+ and 10.8350+ at the highs with the former eyeing next week’s Norges Bank meeting to see if a September hike is still on the cards or the Central Bank folds given no less than 6 peers easing this week in the face of heightened growth concerns (not to mention slower economic expansion levels already evident).

EM 

Contrasting fortunes across the region, with the Inr and Thb moving in opposite directions after the RBI lopped 35 bp off benchmark rates vs -1/4 point expected and the BoT deciding to cut 25 bp vs unchanged forecast, unlike the BSP, Serbian and Peruvian Central Banks that all delivered ¼ point eases in line with expectations. Meanwhile, the Try continues to outperform with the aid of not as high as feared Turkish CPI and CBRT tweaks to RRRs, while the Zar and Brl lagged/weakened markedly amidst poor SA data and despite Brazil passing its pension reforms.

subject: Nomura quants say Thursday's stock bounce was a relief rally; seasonal patterns suggest rally will pause next week
content:
• Nomura quants attribute Thursday's equity buying -- where the SPX recovered 2900, and NDX to over 7220 -- as a reflexive rebound, given there was no noteworthy news driving the bounce. The bank says "stock market sentiment improved slightly in the US and around the globe. While sentiment remains deep in negative territory (indicating risk aversion), investor psychology appears to be letting go of some of the excessive pessimism that had held sway."
  • Nomura says that the dip-buying by ultra-short term traders (with investment horizons under 10 days) and global hedge funds seems to be colliding with the unwinding of equity long positions by trend-following algos. However, Nomura says that globla macro hedge funds might be ramping up their bullishness again in response to solid economic data out of the US and china, and Nomura says they appear to be making something of a power play in staking out more long positions again. "The upshot of this is that the buying of US equity by fundamentals-oriented human traders overpowered tentative selling attempts by more technically oriented algo traders."
  • Nomura says that global macro hedge funds are still bullish on fundamentals, and have been buying global equities on weakness, particularly in the US. "Even during the US equity sell-off in the earlier part of the week, there was not much unwinding of long positions by macro players," the bank writes, noting that "since 7th August, they have been tentatively buying US and European equity to sound out the market; and while macroeconomic indicators only show the state of the economy in the rear-view mirror, ongoing strength in these indicators in the US and China should provide some support for these bullish stances."
  • In contrast, while CTAs are still looking to pare their long positions, they also seem to be holding back to some extent in the light of the swiftness of the rebound in major market indices, Nomura observes. "The NASDAQ 100 in particular has already recovered to around 7720, the breakeven point for CTAs' existing long positions (the cost of net buying of future since June), relieving some of the pressure for mechanistic selling," and while the S&P 500 is still some way away from the breakeven point around 2960, "it may be worth considering the possibility that macro players may intentionally push prices up to stem the selling by the systematic traders."
  • Nevertheless, Nomura still questions the sustainability of the rally, and still sees it as a mere relief rally following the plunge. "Many aspects of this rally are following predictable patterns, arguably in keeping with the market's own particular rhythm," Nomura says, "the rally looks likely to pause next week, and we think investors should cautiously watch the prospects for another 'vol-up' scenario in the latter half of August."
  • Nomura notes that the pace of macro indicators tends to show up in the APAC region from around mid-August, and in the US from the end of August. "Considering that the current bullishness among macro investors may have been catalyzed by the upswing in these indicators, these investors' equity buying could lose speed as early as mid-August."
  • On volatility, the bank notes that VVIX has been moving in line with the usual seasonal patterns: "Assuming that the present decline in the VVIX is also in line with the usual schedule, we see concerns over another market drop in late-August," Nomura states, "there has been no increase in call buying in the VIX options market, so investors do not seem adequately prepared for a vol-up scenario."
  • Nomura looked through data since 1994 to see the average pattern for the SPX during phases where the VIX spikes a second time in the space of 10 to 30 days after the first, and notes that prices appear to be following a similar pattern (with 6 August as day 0), and if the pattern holds, the bank would expect the recovery in share prices to hit its peak around 14th August, six trading days after the first spike.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 9th August 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European indices are firmly in negative territory [Euro Stoxx 50 -1.0%], as the mixed Asia-Pac handover fizzled out
  • BTPs, FTSE MIB and Italian Banks are under significant pressure as recent reports indicate League Party are to present a no-confidence motion in the Government
  • UK GDP Prelim QQ Q2 -0.2% vs. Exp. 0.0%, after which Sterling touched multi-year lows at 1.2080
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, include US PPI, Canadian Building Permits & Jobs Data

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mostly higher as the region got a mild tailwind from the strong performance on Wall St where stocks extended their rebound, helped by the recent better than expected Chinese trade data and continued PBoC restraint on the CNY. As such, ASX 200 (+0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) were higher with notable strength seen in tech stocks after similar gains in the sector stateside and with investors in Tokyo cheering better than expected GDP data, although weakness in real estate and profit taking in gold miners has limited the upside for Australia. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.7%) were choppy with initial support seen after the PBoC once again set a firmer than expected reference rate but with gains later pared after participants digested mixed inflation data in which CPI topped estimates but PPI contracted, while reports the US held off on the decision regarding Huawei licences after China stopped agricultural purchases, added to the cautiousness. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher as they track upside in T-notes and as prices broke through prior at 154.50/55, with the BoJ also present in the market under its bond buying program in which it upped purchases in 1-3yr JGBs but lowered purchases of 3-5yr and 10-25yr maturities.

PBoC skipped open market operations and are net neutral for the week vs. last week's CNY 50bln net drain. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0136 vs. Exp. 7.0222 (Prev. 7.0039)

US delayed the decision regarding Huawei licenses following China’s suspension of agricultural purchases. (Newswires)

Chinese CPI (Jul) Y/Y 2.8% vs. Exp. 2.7% (Prev. 2.7%). Chinese PPI (Jul) Y/Y -0.3% vs. Exp. -0.1% (Prev. 0.0%)

Japanese GDP (Q2 P) 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.1% (Prev. 0.6%). Japanese GDP (Q2 P) Y/Y 1.8% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. 2.2%)

China Q2 prelim current account surplus USD 57bln; H1 surplus USD 106bln; a small 2019 current account surplus is expected, according to FX regulator. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US Defence Secretary Esper has asked South Korea to send troops to the Strait of Hormuz. (Newswires)

Iranian Foreign Ministry spokesperson says any Israel involvement in any maritime coalition in the Gulf is a "clear threat" to national security, which Iran has a right to confront the threat. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK Opposition Labour leader Corbyn has written to Cabinet Secretary Sedwill expressing his concern regarding the potential for PM Johnson to use the fact that parliament is dissolved 25 days prior to a general election as a means to push a no-deal Brexit through during such a period. (BBC)

Italy's League Party to present in the Senate a no-confident motion in the government, adds that elections must be held quickly, according to a statement. Italian Deputy PM Salvini reportedly said the League are ready for a confidence vote as soon as next week. While, Italian President Mattarella reportedly may seek 'Guarantee' government before Monday's confidence vote, according to Corriere della Sera (Newswires)

UK GDP Prelim QQ Q2 -0.2% Exp. 0.0% (Prev. 0.5%); first quarterly contraction since 2012

- UK GDP Prelim YY Q2 1.2% vs. Exp. 1.4% (Prev. 1.8%)

- ONS: “GDP contracted in the second quarter for the first time since 2012 after robust growth in the first quarter. Manufacturing output fell back after a strong start to the year, with production brought forward ahead of the UK’s original departure date from the EU"

EQUITIES

Major European indices have diverted from their Asia-Pac counterparts largely positive performance and opened and remain in negative territory [Euro Stoxx 50 -1.0%]. The FTSE MIB (-2.2%) is the notable underperformer this morning as the Italian political turmoil has escalated following comments from League’s Salvini that there is no longer a majority of support for the government and elections are necessary (a summary of the situation is available on the headline feed). The MIB’s underperformance is most significantly driven by banking names with the likes of UniCredit (-6.0%), UBI Banca (-6.0%) and Banco BPM (-8.3%) experiencing significant losses; as such, the FTSE MIB Banking Index is lagging (-4.4%) with the largest weighted bank in the Stoxx 600 Bank index (-1.5%), Intesa Sanpaolo (-4.5%), with a 3.8% weighting likely the most significant laggard out of Italy in terms of index points. Elsewhere, the DAX (-0.6%) did get a short-lived boost from a Bayer (+3.2%) update, where reported indicate the Co. are to propose up to a USD 8bln roundup settlement; which generated a significant spike in Co. shares from around EUR 63.50 to EUR 70.00 at best. DAX aside, this morning’s notable movers to the upside largely reside in the FTSE 100 (-0.2%), with WPP (+7.3%) topping the index higher post earnings where the Co. proposed an interim dividend of GBP 0.0266 and H1 net revenue came in above the prior. Sticking with the UK, but outside of the 100 are Hikma Pharmaceuticals (+6.8%) as the Co’s H1 revenue also came in above prior and additionally the Co. increased some FY guidance components.

Tesla (TSLA) - Elon Musk tweets that CO's software V10 is looking really good, will be releasing to early access list soon. (Twitter)

FX

GBP/EUR - The Pound has come under renewed pressure on the back of an unexpected, but not exactly shocking negative UK GDP print for Q2, while monthly IP and output data also missed expectations. However, Cable has dipped below the 1.2080 multi-year base and Eur/Gbp has just crossed yesterday’s 2 year high at 0.9265. given the single currency’s separate struggles in wake of more Italian political instability. Indeed, Eur/Usd remains capped around 1.1200 after the collapse of Rome’s 2-party coalition, and ahead of a confidence vote before fresh elections potentially in October or November, while circa 1 bn option expiries at the big figure and from 1.1175-60 may also keep the headline pair in check into Friday’s NY cut.

JPY/CHF/NZD/AUD/CAD - All mildly firmer against the Greenback, albeit well within this week’s ranges and for the Yen that means largely anchored on 106.00 as Fib resistance just above (106.06) continues to be respected on a closing basis, while decent expiry interest between 105.90-106.00 could stall pull-backs towards 105.50. Meanwhile, the Franc has rebounded through 0.9750 and 1.0900 vs the Euro on the aforementioned renewed political uncertainty in Italy and the Antipodean Dollars are still clawing back post-RBNZ declines vs their US counterpart even though RBA comments and the SOMP overnight have underscored clear downside economic risks that will likely require further monetary, or perhaps even unconventional easing. Hence, Aud/Usd looks vulnerable above 0.6800 and Nzd/Usd just shy of 0.6500 as the Aussie/Kiwi cross pivots 1.0500. Turning to the Loonie, looming Canadian jobs and to a lesser extent perhaps housing data should provide some independent impetus as crude prices essentially tread water approaching the end of a volatile week and the DXY stays close to 97.5000. Usd/Cad currently trading towards the base of 1.3245-15 parameters.

NOK/SEK - The Scandi Crowns are flat-lining against the Euro after some relatively big swings so far this week, with Eur/Nok and Eur/Sek meandering between 9.9955-9665 and 10.7475-7070 respectively and neither really reacting to data as Norwegian inflation metrics and Swedish household consumption updates were both somewhat mixed.

EM - Broad losses vs the Buck as the overall risk tone sours again and specific bearish factors persist, while the Lira has also been subject to fresh reports about more Government interference at the CBRT (at least 9 senior personnel ‘given’ new roles, according to the FT). Elsewhere, the Yuan continues to weaken after another seemingly off-radar incrementally higher PBoC Usd/Cny mid-point fix (at 7.0136).

At least nine senior figures at the CBRT, including the chief economist, Hakan Kara, were told on Thursday that they were being moved to other roles, according to two people familiar with the matter. (FT)

RBA Governor Lowe said Australian economy is to expand 2.5% this year in which the downward revision reflects weak consumption growth but added he expects quarterly GDP growth to increase gradually and suggested the economy may have reached a "gentle turning point", while he suggested fiscal option should be on the table if demand weakens and that monetary policy has a role to play but would like other options explored. Furthermore, Governor Lowe said they are prepared to use unconventional policy if warranted and that it is possible we head to zero lower bound, although he hopes it can be avoided and added that unconventional policy in Australia is unlikely. (Newswires)

RBA Statement on Monetary Policy reiterated that the board is prepared to ease policy if needed and are observing the labour market, while it added that it is reasonable to expect extended period of low rates, that near-term risks are more to the downside and that economic forecasts include technical assumption rates will move in line with market pricing of a cut to 0.75% by year-end and to 0.5% in H1 next year. RBA lowered GDP growth forecast for Dec. 2019 to 2.50% from 2.75%, maintained Dec. 2020 forecast at 2.75% and raised June 2021 forecast to 3.00% from 2.75%, while it sees underlying inflation for Dec. 2019 at 1.50% (Prev. 1.75%), Dec, 2020 at 1.75% (Prev. 2.00%) and for June 2021 at 2.00% (Prev. 2.00%). (Newswires)

Notable FX Option Expiries:

- EUR/USD: 1.1100 (570M), 1.1160-75 (1B), 1.1200 (975M), 1.1245-50 (550M)

- USDJPY: 105.90-106.00 (1.3B), 106.90-107.00 (700M), 107.25 (420M)

FIXED INCOME

UK debt looks set to extend post-UK data gains from 134.43 currently and further outpace Bunds that have lost some momentum, but the big bond story of the session so far in terms of price action remains political and prompted by the collapse of Rome’s coalition Government. Indeed, the 10 Italian benchmark has now been as low as 137.13 (-288 ticks on the day) and the corresponding yield up over 1.80% at one stage as investors await confirmation of a vote of no confidence that could come later today. Meanwhile, US Treasuries are shadowing moves in core counterparts and the curve has flipped back into bull-flattening mode after the final leg of this week’s auction remit saw long bonds received more warmly than 10s overall, and with PPI data to come.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures are firmer in early EU trade, albeit the benchmarks have far to go to retrace this week’s losses. The ramp up of US-China trade tensions saw the global benchmark slump to a current weekly low of 55.90/bbl (vs. 61.40/bbl weekly open), whilst WTI found a weekly base at 50.55/bbl (vs. 55.29/bbl weekly open). The former currently eyes 53/bbl (200 WMA 53.05/bbl) to the upside whilst the latter climbs closer towards 58/bbl (200 WMA at 57.76/bbl) . The oil demand outlook has been deteriorating with IEA the latest agency to cut its global demand growth forecast, by 100k BPD to 1.1mln BPD and 2020 by 50k BPD to 1.3mln BPD. The release is relatively in-fitting with EIA’s STEO earlier in the week, where it cut 2019 world oil demand growth forecast by 70k BPD to 1.0mln BPD, but raised its 2020 forecast by 30k BPD to 1.43mln BPD. Prices may also see support from the Saudi’s intention for intervention to stem the decline in the market, although official measures have not been announced. Elsewhere, a stellar week for gold as the yellow metal was bolstered as investors flocked to the safe-haven amid the aforementioned ramp up in protectionism. Spot gold has a current weekly (and 6-year) high of 1510/oz (vs. 1440/oz at the weekly open). BAML Flow Show notes that precious metals have reaped inflows of USD 2.3bln, its fourth largest weekly inflows to date. Meanwhile, copper prices are flat around the USD 2.6/lb level amid the cautious risk tone ahead of US’ market entrance. Sticking with base metals, iron ore prices continue to decline with the metal down 18% thus far this month amid a bleaker short-term demand outlook with steel mills potentially reducing operations on low profitability, whilst exports from Brazil and Australia continue to rise. The Reserve Bank of Australia, at its SoMP, also noted that iron ore prices are “expected to decline further” as supply gradually comes back online and China demand moderates. Finally, nickel prices continue to be supported by the speculation that Indonesia could reel in an export ban on nickel ore in a regulatory move. Indonesia initially planned to ban exporting nickel ore by 2022 in an attempt to build up its manufacturing base by using its raw resources. The country said that no decision has been made on the mineral ore export ban timing but bringing the deadline forward from 2022 will disrupt USD 4bln in ore exports.

CME raised Comex 5000 silver futures margins for August by 13.9% to USD 4100 per contract. (Newswires) ICE is raising margin requirements for ICE Futures US Oil Contract, effective from the close of business on August 12th and which will be reflected in margin calls made the next day. (ICE)

Indonesia says no decision has been on the mineral ore export ban timing but bringing the deadline forward from 2022 will disrupt USD 4bln ore exports. (Newswires)

Russian Energy Ministry says the possibility of slower global oil demand was taken into account when taking the decision to extend OPEC+ output deal. (Newswires)

IEA Monthly Report: cuts 2019 oil demand growth estimate by 100k bpd to 1.1mln bpd and cuts 2020 by 50k bpd to 1.3mln bpd. (Newswires)

- Global oil demand fell 160k bpd Y/Y in May

- Global oil supply held steady in July above 100mln bpd, but fell beneath year earlier levels for the first time since November 2017

- Iranian oil production fell 500k bpd in July to 2.23mln bpd; lowest since 1908's. Iranian oil exports fell 130k bpd in July to 400k bpd

ANALYSIS: ROME’S POLITICAL RUINS
content:
*LONG STORY SHORT: Italy’s Deputy PM and League Leader Salvini have called for a snap election after claiming that there is no longer a majority to support the coalition government. The relationship between his party and the 5-Star Movement reached breaking point over a project for a railway between Italy and France (TAV), as parliament rejected a motion by 5SM to block the plan. 

*WHAT’S NEXT: Italian press has been touting next Monday as the date for a confidence vote against the Conte-led government, although this is not set in stone. Later reports stated that Deputy PM Salvini favours October 13th as the date for an election (Corriere), although other newspapers noted that President Mattarella is mulling October 23rd (La Repubblica), albeit this is subject to the timing of the aforementioned confidence vote. Salvini is currently pressing for a parliamentary debate next week, whilst reports stated that the 5SM favours one after the August 15th national holiday. It’s worth keeping in mind that the Italian parliament is currently on its summer break, but reports state that it could reconvene next week amid the political angst. Following the confidence vote, it rests with President Mattarella to dissolve the government and decide if the next step would be a general election or the installation of a technocratic government in order to pass the Autumn 2020 budget.

Bunds: sharper rebound as BTPs flounder
content: Once again German data has hardly figured, but the 10 year German benchmark has now reversed all and more of Thursday’s climate issuance related losses on the back of a collapse in Italian bonds sparked by more political turmoil in Rome. Indeed, Bunds have been as high as 177.55 vs yesterday’s 176.93 Eurex close and a 176.38 intraday low, while in stark contrast BTPs have succumbed to several waves of selling into tentative bounces and racked up cumulative losses of 262 ticks, so far. Understandably, the 10 year yield has catapulted in turn, to circa 1.75% and bears will now be gunning for 137.37 in the future ahead of 137.03. For Bunds, Wednesday’s 177.74 contract best is obviously an upside target.

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

9th August 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mostly higher as the region got a mild tailwind from the strong performance on Wall St where stocks extended their rebound, helped by the recent better than expected Chinese trade data and continued PBoC restraint on the CNY. content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets traded mostly higher as the region got a mild tailwind from the strong performance on Wall St and continued PBoC restraint on the CNY
  • US delayed the decision regarding Huawei licenses following China’s suspension of agricultural purchases
  • Italian Deputy PM and League leader Salvini said there is no longer a majority to support the government and it is necessary to hold fresh elections
  • AUD/USD tumultuous at the whim of central bank rhetoric including RBA Governor Lowe’s Semi-Annual Testimony and the Statement on Monetary Policy
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US PPI, German Trade, UK GDP, Services, Industrial & Manufacturing Output, Canadian Building Permits & Jobs Data

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mostly higher as the region got a mild tailwind from the strong performance on Wall St where stocks extended their rebound, helped by the recent better than expected Chinese trade data and continued PBoC restraint on the CNY. As such, ASX 200 (+0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) were higher with notable strength seen in tech stocks after similar gains in the sector stateside and with investors in Tokyo cheering better than expected GDP data, although weakness in real estate and profit taking in gold miners has limited the upside for Australia. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.4%) were choppy with initial support seen after the PBoC once again set a firmer than expected reference rate but with gains later pared after participants digested mixed inflation data in which CPI topped estimates but PPI contracted, while reports the US held off on the decision regarding Huawei licences after China stopped agricultural purchases, added to the cautiousness. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher as they track upside in T-notes and as prices broke through prior at 154.50/55, with the BoJ also present in the market under its bond buying program in which it upped purchases in 1-3yr JGBs but lowered purchases of 3-5yr and 10-25yr maturities.

PBoC skipped open market operations and are net neutral for the week vs. last week's CNY 50bln net drain. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0136 vs. Exp. 7.0222 (Prev. 7.0039)

US delayed the decision regarding Huawei licenses following China’s suspension of agricultural purchases. (Newswires)

Chinese CPI (Jul) Y/Y 2.8% vs. Exp. 2.7% (Prev. 2.7%). Chinese PPI (Jul) Y/Y -0.3% vs. Exp. -0.1% (Prev. 0.0%)

Japanese GDP (Q2 P) 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.1% (Prev. 0.6%). Japanese GDP (Q2 P) Y/Y 1.8% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. 2.2%)

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson said Parliament should honour the Brexit vote and leave on October 31st, while he is hopeful and confident that the EU will show flexibility and a willingness to compromise. PM Johnson responded that he is committed to delivering on the Brexit vote when asked about early elections and reiterated there is a good deal to be done once there is change to the backstop issue. (Newswires) UK Opposition Labour leader Corbyn has written to Cabinet Secretary Sedwill expressing his concern regarding the potential for PM Johnson to use the fact that parliament is dissolved 25 days prior to a general election as a means to push a no-deal Brexit through during such a period. (BBC)

UK Foreign Minister Raab reiterated the UK will leave EU in October and that the government would prefer to leave with a deal but if the EU is not flexible, UK will leave on WTO terms. (Newswires)

Italian Deputy PM and League leader Salvini said there is no longer a majority to support the government and it is necessary to hold fresh elections in which he will seek the PM role in an upcoming vote. There were also reports the League are ready for a confidence vote as soon as next week, while Deputy PM Di Maio stated that he is prepared for elections and that Salvini will pay for taking Italy for a ride. (Newswires)

FX

USD slightly softened and re-approached 97.50 to the downside after US President Trump continued his criticism on the Fed and suggested that a strong currency is making it harder for US manufacturers, although price action was very mild and contained within the tight-range seen for most of the week. The greenback’s major counterparts were also uneventful with EUR/USD subdued just below 1.1200 where there is a large option expiry of nearly EUR 1bln for today’s New York cut and with the single currency hampered by Italian government uncertainty, while GBP/USD amid ongoing Brexit uncertainty. Antipodeans took much of the focus with AUD/USD tumultuous at the whim of central bank rhetoric including RBA Governor Lowe’s Semi-Annual Testimony and the Statement on Monetary Policy. The currency eventually benefited despite the central bank reiterating it is prepared to ease policy if needed, that it is reasonable to expect an extended period of low rates and noted that near-term risks are more to downside, as the comments didn’t suggest much urgency for an immediate cut and Governor Lowe also stated the economy may have reached a gentle turning point. Furthermore, there was brief bout of pressure after Lowe touched upon unconventional policies which he said they were prepared to use if warranted and that there was a possibility we head to zero lower bound on rates, but the pressure to the currency was short-lived as he also suggested that this was unlikely.

At least nine senior figures at the CBRT, including the chief economist, Hakan Kara, were told on Thursday that they were being moved to other roles, according to two people familiar with the matter. (FT)

RBA Governor Lowe said Australian economy is to expand 2.5% this year in which the downward revision reflects weak consumption growth but added he expects quarterly GDP growth to increase gradually and suggested the economy may have reached a "gentle turning point", while he suggested fiscal option should be on the table if demand weakens and that monetary policy has a role to play but would like other options explored. Furthermore, Governor Lowe said they are prepared to use unconventional policy if warranted and that it is possible we head to zero lower bound, although he hopes it can be avoided and added that unconventional policy in Australia is unlikely. (Newswires)

RBA Statement on Monetary Policy reiterated that the board is prepared to ease policy if needed and are observing the labour market, while it added that it is reasonable to expect extended period of low rates, that near-term risks are more to the downside and that economic forecasts include technical assumption rates will move in line with market pricing of a cut to 0.75% by year-end and to 0.5% in H1 next year. RBA lowered GDP growth forecast for Dec. 2019 to 2.50% from 2.75%, maintained Dec. 2020 forecast at 2.75% and raised June 2021 forecast to 3.00% from 2.75%, while it sees underlying inflation for Dec. 2019 at 1.50% (Prev. 1.75%), Dec, 2020 at 1.75% (Prev. 2.00%) and for June 2021 at 2.00% (Prev. 2.00%). (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were relatively flat overnight with WTI crude future little-changed as it continues on from the lack of direction seen yesterday where prices oscillated predominantly within the confines of the USD 52 handle amid opposing factors such as the resumption of limited output at Libya’s largest oilfield and with OPEC members reiterating their commitment to the output agreement and keeping the oil market balanced. Gold prices were uneventful with only minimal gains seen amid a weaker greenback and as the USD 1500/oz level provided a base for the precious metal, while copper also conformed to sideways trade as the early momentum in its largest buyer China eventually waned.

 

UAE Energy Minister said they remain committed to the OPEC and non-OPEC agreement, which has brought greater market balance and improved market stability, while they will continue to support actions which balance the oil market and he is confident OPEC/NON-OPEC members will take a similar stance. (Newswires)

 

Libya's El Sharara Oil Field (300k BPD) restarted production at a limited level of output, according a source. (Newswires)

 

Iraq is close to reaching a deal with BP and Eni to build twin seabed pipelines for oil exports in the Gulf which had originally been part of Iraq's USD 53bln project will Exxon, according to Iraqi sources. (Newswires)

 

CME raised Comex 5000 silver futures margins for August by 13.9% to USD 4100 per contract. (Newswires) ICE is raising margin requirements for ICE Futures US Oil Contract, effective from the close of business on August 12th and which will be reflected in margin calls made the next day. (ICE)

 

GEOPOLITICS

 

US President Trump tweeted that Iran is in serious financial trouble and they want to talk to the US, but they are given mixed signals from all of those purporting to represent us including French President Macron. (Twitter) 

US

Trade wars, low inflation, and commentary suggesting neutral rates may be lower than previously seen has been driving the rally in bonds this week, but the rally paused on Thursday after the PBOC overnight weakened the yuan fix by less than models had suggested. The curve was bear steepening in early trade, and yields saw further upside in sympathy with EGBs, on reports that Germany was mulling raising issuance; the report was denied by the Germans, and the Bund gradually pared back the knee-jerk downside. The US sold 30-year bonds sold at 2.335%, tailing 1.2bps. Cover picked up from the prior, and came in in line with recent averages; dealer participation fell from the prior, though was a touch short t=of the recent average; direct participation fell versus the prior, but was still short of the six auction averages. Indirect participation recovered to above 60%, rising from the prior and above recent averages. After the auction, T-Note futures continued rose, though still end the day with yields higher across the curve (2s +4bps, 5s +3.4bps, 10s +2.6bps, 30s +4.4bps). US T-note futures (U9) settled 7+ ticks lower 129-29+.

content:
Asia equity markets trade mostly higher as the region gets a mild tailwind from the strong performance on Wall St where stocks extended their rebound, helped by the recent better than expected Chinese trade data and continued PBoC restraint on the CNY. As such, ASX 200 (+0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) are higher with notable strength seen in tech stocks after similar gains in the sector stateside and with investors in Tokyo cheering better than expected GDP data, although weakness in real estate and profit taking in gold miners has limited the upside for Australia. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.4%) are choppy with initial support seen after the PBoC once again set a firmer than expected reference rate but with gains later pared after participants digested mixed inflation data in which CPI topped estimates but PPI contracted, while reports the US held off on the decision regarding Huawei licences after China stopped agricultural purchases also added to the cautiousness.

In FX markets, the USD is slightly softer after US President Trump continued his criticism on the Fed and suggested that a strong currency is making it harder for US manufacturers, with the DXY re-approaching the 97.50 level to the downside but with price action very mild and contained within the tight-range seen for most of the week. The greenback’s major counterparts are also uneventful with EUR/USD subdued just below 1.1200 where there is a large option expiry of nearly EUR 1bln for today’s New York cut and with the single currency hampered by Italian government uncertainty amid a breakdown in the ruling coalition partnership between League and 5SM which could see a confidence vote as soon as next week, while GBP/USD is also cautious amid a lack of any fresh Brexit developments and with both sides of the Channel unwilling to budge. Elsewhere, antipodeans took much of the focus with AUD/USD tumultuous at the whim of central bank rhetoric including RBA Governor Lowe’s Semi-Annual Testimony and the Statement on Monetary Policy. The currency eventually benefited despite the central bank reiterating it is prepared to ease policy if needed, that it is reasonable to expect an extended period of low rates and noted that near-term risks are more to downside, as the comments didn’t suggest much urgency for an immediate cut and Governor Lowe also stated the economy may have reached a gentle turning point. Furthermore, there was brief bout of pressure after Lowe later touched upon unconventional policies which he said they were prepared to use if warranted and that there was a possibility we head to zero lower bound on rates, but the pressure to the currency was short-lived as he also suggested that this was unlikely.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are higher as they track upside in T-notes and with the BoJ also present in the market under its bond buying program in which it upped purchases in 1-3yr JGBs but lowered purchases of 3-5yr and 10-25yr maturities.

content:
